---
title: 'Assessment Teams Experience of Barriers and Challenges When Assessing Loneliness
  and Depression Among Home‐Dwelling Elderly: A Qualitative Study'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-K7F9XTDA" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Hauger, B., Martinsen, R., Hestad, K., &#38; Ødbehr, L. S. (2025). Assessment Teams Experience of Barriers and Challenges When Assessing Loneliness and Depression Among Home‐Dwelling Elderly: A Qualitative Study. <i>Scandinavian Journal of Caring Sciences</i>, <i>39</i>(2). <a href="https://doi.org/10.1111/scs.70026">https://doi.org/10.1111/scs.70026</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-K7F9XTDA" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-K7F9XTDA" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Hauger et al. conducted a study published in the Scandinavian Journal of Caring Sciences, exploring the challenges faced by care assessment teams in evaluating loneliness and depression among elderly people receiving home care in Norway. They found that mental health issues are often overlooked because physical health is prioritized, and a formal diagnosis is necessary to receive mental health support. Additionally, there are significant differences in mental health services between municipalities. The study highlights that organizational and administrative barriers prevent effective mental health interventions, leading to loneliness and depression being underreported. The authors suggest that both caseworkers and municipal leaders need to develop systems that ensure comprehensive care for the elderly, addressing both physical and mental health needs.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-K7F9XTDA" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Loneliness, Depression, Elderly Care, Home Care, Mental Health Support, Municipal Services
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-K7F9XTDA" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    BackgroundLoneliness and depression in the elderly population are a worldwide challenge. Elderly people receiving home care are very vulnerable, as they often suffer from comorbidity and various other challenges.AimThe study aim was to explore how care assessment teams experience assessing loneliness and symptoms of depression among home care recipients aged 65 years and older in planned home visits.MethodThis study has a qualitative design. Data were collected during two phases. First, data from documents were collected in seven municipalities on 168 home care decisions made by assessment units during 1 month. Second, 10 caseworkers and 10 case managers from different care assessment teams in 20 municipalities located in four different regions in Norway were individually interviewed. Both data sources were analysed using qualitative content analysis.ResultsAnalysis of the documents revealed that only three of the 168 home care decisions described support for mental health. The analysis of the interviews resulted in three themes: (i) ‘Physical health has higher priority than mental health in home care’, (ii) ‘Being diagnosed is essential to receive support from home care’, (iii) ‘Major differences in mental health support between municipalities’.ConclusionCaseworkers in care assessment teams find that many home‐dwelling elderly are struggling with loneliness and depression, but barriers on both organisational and administrative levels prevent them from providing appropriate interventions. Mental health is thus not systematically recorded in assessments, which may lead to loneliness and depression being overlooked. There are significant differences between municipalities regarding service offerings and follow‐up procedures for loneliness and depression, and both caseworkers and municipal leadership must ensure a system that provides comprehensive patient care.
  </article>
